Problem:
class HealthReport { int calories; bool exercise; int stressLevel; void updateExercise(bool didExercise) { exercise = didExercise; if (didExercise) { calories -= 100; } } void updateStressLevel(int workHours) { if (workHours > 8) { stressLevel += 5; } else if (workHours < 5) { stressLevel -= 3; } } }",

If we modify the number of work hours to below 5 in the updateStressLevel, will this necessarily reduce the stress level?
Explanation: Per the updateStressLevel method logic, reducing work hours below 5 leads to a decrease in stress level by 3 units, which is an intended and direct consequence of the function's execution.

List only distinct and meaningful causal relations. Do not provide any final answer to the question. Focus only on extracting the causal structure. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "A → B; C → D; ..."}.
causal_map: workHours → stressLevel; workHours → exercise; exercise → calories; workHours → stressLevel
